I dont think its better. These robots are like animals made out of just ligaments. I prefer a bone to ligament to bone, Muscle to tendon to bone system. As I get older I can really understand the value of strong ligaments, as I lose these with age. I can exercise the muscle but if the ligaments are loose then the structure begins to grind the joints as it gones out of optimal position. Why not use ligaments with robots ? The ligament connects a bone to a bone. Tendon is muscle to bone. Ligaments allow bending and structural strength, Muscles are the motors, Bone supports structure and give the muscle something hard to push against, as does tight skin.

Had an idea in my head to work around this concept. Video added to the vision. Why a snake chainsaw? Why would you do it any other way? It's not fast but it's safe. A flying drone or climbing drone would likely have some dead weight and extraneous elements that serve to impede movement and function. Snakes have a very good center of gravity and that applies well for climbing and gripping. A snake isn't going to be caught up in every possible difficult situation where a flier would have. I could see a snake being modular in some beneficial ways.

It's also distracting, watching the unnatural mask wearing and thinking a bit more of pandemic and fear, instead of just this amazing tech.

So where possible, it would be so much better if masks could be removed where permitted, just for the recording of the video. Then we can focus better on the content, and understand what is being said more easily. I reside in Sweden where masks are fortunately not so common, which may be part of my perception, but it does detract from watching the video, so just sharing my experience is affected here.

Love the idea and the fact that he's thinking outside the box, but from an engineering standpoint this seems like a system that would be prone to errors and not function well in a real world environment. Notice how we don't see the robot ever traverse on anything other than mats or in a controlled environment. As I said, I like it, but it's not a realistic mechanism for operating on other planets nor do we even know how well it holds up in a proper stress test (And before you say it, yeah, they messed with the nylon tubes but that doesn't properly stress test the joints and the mechanism controlling the tubes moving).

Keep working at it, but I, personally, don't see this current iteration going anywhere without some serious changes to design and overall structure.

Regarding leaks, other than adding small compressors, they can try adding something like a tire repair fluid, which can be used to automatically seal a hole, even during operation. That way, the compressor would not need to run continuously, saving on energy cost, especially in space missions. Also, the compressors need not be high powered...even a weak compressor with minimal power requirements can be used and run off solar/wind power or other "green" sources. It might take a little longer to (re)inflate, but will help keep mass and energy requirements lower.

The pneumatic turtlebot is an awesome concept, but I doubt its ability to actually be useful in an environment where they can't have electronics. That would mean no cameras to see where it's going, so a human would need to be relatively close. There would be no instrumentation for analysis, so no real capability beyond locomotion. It would also mean it requires a long bundle of tubes running back to the controls, which would severely limit its range due to the load it has to carry just to move.

Awesome concept, and I'm sure there will be some cool uses for the bot, but use in electrically volatile areas isn't one of them until we figure out some way to replace all of the other electrical components that are required to make it actually useful in those environments.

One way to get around the leaking issue could be to use metal strips like you find in tape measures. The curve along the width of the tape measure gives it strength,  when you reach a vertex the rollers would flatten it out and allow the metal strip to roll through the vertex. Using a  mechanism like on a clothing zipper you could roll the metal strip into a tube to ensure that it doesn't bend accidentally, at each vertex it would be unzipped and unrolled, passed through the rollers and then zipped up on the other end. This way you could also store a spool of extra metal at the vertices where the metal strip terminates and change the perimeter (therefore volume) of the robot.
